column1: By Michelle Conlin and Caren Bohan
| NEW YORK/WASHINGTON

NEW YORK/WASHINGTON U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren has considered the idea of serving as Hillary Clinton's running mate but sees obstacles to that choice as she prepares to endorse the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee
column2: several people familiar with Warren's thinking told Reuters.While her thinking could evolve
column3: Warren has concerns about joining a Clinton ticket
column4: including the question of whether running two women would give the Democrats the best shot at defeating Republican Donald Trump
column5: one source said.      Advisers to Warren
column6: a fiery critic of Wall Street and a  popular figure among progressive Democrats
column7: have been in close contact with Clinton's campaign team and the conversations have increased in frequency in recent weeks
column8: the sources said. Warren has signaled to people close to her that she is intrigued by the possibility of being Clinton's No. 2 but has not discussed the role with Clinton
column10: or anyone else from her campaign
column13: has been one of the Democrats' most outspoken critics of Trump
column15: and her priority is helping to defeat the presumptive Republican nominee in the Nov. 8 presidential election
column16: the sources said. Warren is also committed to advancing her own political agenda
column17: which they described as ""more progressive"" than Clinton's more centrist positions. Warren fears that as vice president
column19: her voice could be less heard than it is in the U.S. Senate on her priority issues such as addressing income inequality
column20: the sources said.  In the past
column21: Warren has accused Clinton of abandoning her support for stronger bankruptcy legislation to try to appease Wall Street.

column1: 'GET READY DONALD'
An endorsement of Clinton could come within a week or two
column2: one of the sources said. Clinton has been appealing for Democratic Party unity. On Twitter over the weekend
column3: Warren echoed that call and emphasized the importance of the party coming together to beat Trump.""Get ready
column4: Donald
column5: Warren tweeted. ""We're coming.""

column1: Warren
column2: who represents Massachusetts in the U.S. Senate
column3: has stayed neutral in the Democratic primary race
column4: notably remaining the only woman senator not throwing her support behind the first woman presidential nominee of a major U.S. political party.Were she to join the Clinton ticket
column5: she could help energize progressives and win over supporters of Clinton's rival Bernie Sanders
column6: a democratic socialist U.S. senator from Vermont. Sanders' calls for reining in Wall Street and breaking up big banks dovetail with Warren's views.An ongoing feud with Trump gained steam on social media with a series of posts in which she labeled the celebrity businessman racist
column7: sexist and xenophobic and said she was going to fight to make sure his ""toxic stew of hatred and insecurity never reaches the White House.""

column1: Warren joined Clinton late last month in criticizing Trump for rooting for the 2008 financial crisis and delivered a 10-minute invective on the subject at an annual Washington gala two weeks ago.""What kind of a man roots for people to get thrown out of their house? I'll tell you exactly what kind of man does that
column2: Warren said. ""It is a man who cares about no one but himself - a small insecure money-grubber who doesn't care who gets hurt so long as he makes a profit off it.""Trump has ridiculed Warren by calling her Pocahontas in a mocking reference to her having said in the past that she had Native American ancestry. Pocahontas was a famous Native American in early colonial Virginia.Warren is due to speak to the American Constitution Society
column3: a progressive legal group
column4: on Thursday at a time when Democrats and some Republicans have criticized Trump's comments about Mexican-American Judge Gonzalo Curiel. (Additional reporting by Megan Cassella and Amanda Becker in Washington; Editing by Amran Abocar
column5: Kevin Krolicki and Howard Goller)"	['Clinton'

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-democrats-idUSKCN0YU2PX	Wooing Sanders supporters will be tough task for Clinton	"
By John Whitesides and Amanda Becker
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Winning over Bernie Sanders supporters who flocked to his insurgent presidential campaign will be the first and possibly toughest order of business for Hillary Clinton after she became the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee this week.Every time the Vermont senator mentioned Clinton's name at a rally in California on Thursday night
column2: his supporters booed as if she was Donald Trump
column3: the Republican businessman who will face off against Clinton in the Nov. 8 election.But Clinton is wasting no time in launching her charm offensive. She called Sanders on Tuesday night
column4: and during a celebratory rally in Brooklyn she praised his candidacy
column5: saying their ""vigorous debate"" during the nominating contest had been good for the Democratic Party. Democrats in both camps said they expect to see more specific olive branches offered to Sanders in the weeks ahead
column6: including compromises on the issues platform to be adopted at the party's July nominating convention and reforms in a Democratic primary process that Sanders criticized as rigged to favor the establishment.It may not be an easy sell for all of Sander's supporters
column7: who have helped catapult him from political obscurity into the national spotlight
column8: cheering his message on income inequality
column9: campaign finance reform and Wall Street excesses. Given little chance a year ago
column10: Sanders earned nearly 10 million votes and won more than 20 states during the nominating process.A Reuters/Ipsos poll in May found Sanders supporters have become increasingly resistant to Clinton in the past few months
column11: with less than half saying they will vote for her if she becomes the party's nominee.Last month
column12: 41 percent of Sanders' supporters said they would vote for Clinton over Trump in the general election. But that was down from 50 percent in April
column13: and 52 percent in March.And some groups supporting Sanders plan to ramp up the pressure on superdelegates
column14: prominent party officials who can vote for any candidate
column15: in the last few weeks before Clinton's nomination becomes official at the party convention in Philadelphia.

column1: The people behind the Occupy DNC Convention Facebook group
column2: with around 25
column3: 000 members
column4: are creating their own web-based app to contact superdelegates
column5: planning daily emails to urge them to switch to Sanders.CLINTON'S TRUMP CARD

column1: Clinton moved to the left to fend off Sanders during the primary battle
column2: opposing the Trans-Pacific Partnership
column3: an Asian trade pact
column4: and the Keystone oil pipeline from Canada
column5: voicing support for a higher minimum wage and backing Sanders' general goals of reining in Wall Street and reducing income inequality.Her best move now to win over progressive voters who backed Sanders would be showing she will stand behind those positions.

column1: One of the biggest points of skepticism that we hear from Sanders supporters and even lukewarm Clinton supporters is the question of whether she really meant the stuff she said in the primary
column2: said Adam Green
column3: co-founder of the Progressive Change Campaign Committee.""The next two weeks are a golden opportunity to make the answer apparent
column4: he said
column5: citing her pledges to seek criminal sentences for financial fraud
column6: break up banks that pose economic risks and expand Social Security benefits.Several Democrats said Trump may prove to be the chief motivator for Sanders supporters to switch to Clinton.""Trump has done more than anyone to push the Sanders people toward Clinton for the general election
column8: an Iowa-based Democratic strategist who supported Clinton in the primary and said he has seen signs of a shift in the last few weeks.

column1: Clinton could make specific concessions or overtures to assuage Sanders
column2: particularly by eliminating the superdelegates from the primary process. Sanders has complained about the involvement of superdelegates
column3: who have heavily backed Clinton.Another easy way to get Sanders' most passionate supporters on board is to simply hire them
column4: says Democratic strategist Steve Schale.That's what Schale
column5: a Florida-based staffer for President Barack Obama's 2008 presidential campaign
column6: did once the bitter primary fight between Obama and Clinton ended that year. Florida was crucial to Obama's prospects -- and his campaign need a large operation to work on voter registration
column8: and turnout.Clinton could offer Sanders diehards a similar opportunity to stay involved. ""For a lot of these folks
column9: the campaign is as much as social calling as it is a movement
column10: he said.While there were concerns in 2008 that Clinton's supporters would be too disaffected to support Obama
column11: Clinton endorsed him less than a month after the primary ended and unified the party.Democratic party leaders may also help ease tensions. Sanders will meet on Thursday with Obama and Senate Democratic leader Harry Reid of Nevada. (Additional reporting by Luciana Lopez and Chris Kahn in New York

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-alabama-marriage-idUSKCN0YU2SY	Judge issues final order upholding Alabama same-sex marriage	"
By Karen Brooks
A federal judge in Alabama has issued a permanent injunction barring state officials from denying same-sex couples the right to marry in that state
column2: according to court documents made public on Wednesday. The order
column3: filed on Tuesday by U.S. District Judge Callie Granade
column4: came in response to a 2014 lawsuit challenging Alabama's ban on same-sex marriage
column5: finalizing a decision Granade made in early 2015 that the state law was unconstitutional. The legality of gay marriage was at the center of a national debate until the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in June 2015 that the U.S. Constitution provided same-sex couples the right to marry.Despite that order
column6: Alabama officials continued to resist the change in the law. Last month
column7: Alabama Supreme Court Chief Justice Roy Moore was suspended for issuing an administrative order to state probate judges that they should not issue marriage licenses to same-sex couples.

column1: In March
column2: the Alabama Supreme Court dismissed petitions by opponents of same-sex marriage asking to reinstate the ban on those unions but refused to vacate or withdraw its own March 2015 ruling in favor of the same-sex marriage ban
column3: made just months before the U.S. Supreme Court ruling.""This brings a finality by permanently prohibiting Alabama from enforcing its marriage laws which are discriminating against gay couples
column4: said Susan Watson
column5: executive director of the ACLU of Alabama. ""Given Alabama's fierce resistance
column6: this permanent relief was required to ensure marriage equality in the state.""

column1: Officials from the office of Alabama Attorney General Luther Strange
column2: who is named in the lawsuit
column3: could not be reached for comment on Wednesday. Strange's attorneys had asked for the lawsuit to be dismissed because the state was currently complying with the federal law. But Granade said in her ruling that ""promising to sin no more"" did not render a permanent injunction unnecessary. The actions of the suspended chief justice and other officials suggested that other attempts may be made to undermine the constitutional right of same-sex couples to marry
column4: she wrote.

column1: It cannot be said with assurance that there is no reasonable expectation that Alabama's unconstitutional marriage laws will not again be enforced
column2: the order said. (Reporting by Karen Brooks in Fort Worth
column3: Texas; Editing by Peter Cooney)"	['Moore']	['gay']

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-arrests-idUSKCN0YV0E2	Three teenagers arrested over assaults during California Trump protest	"

column2: California
column3: police said. The three unidentified juveniles
column4: all males
column5: were accused of taking part in a number of skirmishes between Trump supporters and anti-Trump demonstrators last Thursday outside the San Jose Convention Center. Trump held a rally there in the lead-up to Tuesday's California primary for the Republican party's presidential nomination.Two of the teenagers
column6: aged 16 and 17
column7: face charges of felony assault with a deadly weapon. The third
column10: the San Jose Police Department said in a statement.One of the teenagers is accused of using a blunt object to strike a victim from behind. The victim suffered visible injuries

column1: Four others were arrested during the protests last week. Two 19-year-olds and an 18-year-old face charges of felony assault with a deadly weapon
column2: while another 19-year-old faces a misdemeanor charge of refusal to disperse. It is unclear whether the seven charged were Trump supporters or among the hundreds of protesters who were seen on news clips waving Mexican flags

column1: Protesters

column3: have gathered at his rallies for months.

column1: Trump

column1: 4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-california-naked-idUSKCN0YV05P	California voting expert bares naked truth about politics	"
By Sharon Bernstein
| SACRAMENTO
column2: Calif.

column1: SACRAMENTO
column2: Calif. Political consultants are sometimes accused of hiding the naked truth about the candidates they represent or the campaigns they devise.But California voting expert Paul Mitchell bared it all after Tuesday's primary election
column3: running naked around the grounds of the state Capitol building in Sacramento after his prediction in a key race turned out to be wrong.""When improbable things happen
column4: some pay consequences
column5: Mitchell posted on Twitter early on Wednesday morning. Along with the posting was a photo of the darkened Capitol
column6: a map of a running route from the athletic tracking app Strava and the title
column8: Mitchell firmly dismissed predictions that two Democrats would be chosen in Tuesday's primary to vie for the state's open U.S. Senate seat in November.

column1: He was so sure that would not happen - despite a change in the state's open primary law advancing the top two vote-getters to the general election regardless of party affiliation - that he vowed to run naked around the Capitol if two Democrats were chosen. When it became clear on Tuesday night that state Attorney General Kamala Harris and U.S. Representative Loretta Sanchez
column2: both Democrats
column3: topped the polls and would advance to the general election
column4: Mitchell knew what he had to do.

column1: He parked his car in front of the Capitol building in downtown Sacramento in the darkest spot he could find
column2: took off his clothes (including shoes) and ran
column3: he said in a telephone interview on Wednesday.    ""I couldn't put up with all the badgering I would get if I didn't do it
column4: he said. ""There's honor among politicos
column5: I guess.""

column1: He managed to maintain his privacy to all but a couple of youths on skateboards.""It really doesn't seem like it's very dark outside when you're streaking
column2: Mitchell said. (Reporting by Sharon Bernstein; Editing by Peter Cooney)"	['Paul'

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-security-ryan-idUSKCN0YV09I	U.S. House Speaker Ryan offers election-year security agenda	"
By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. House Speaker Paul Ryan unveiled a national security policy featuring stronger defense on Thursday
column2: the next step in a conservative policy agenda rolling out as he works to unify Republicans after a divisive primary campaign.The plan is sharply critical of President Barack Obama
column3: blaming the Democrat for ""eight years of broken promises
column4: concessions
column5: and retreat"" in the Syrian civil war
column6: nuclear deal with Iran
column7: chilly relations with Russia and dealings with a bellicose North Korea.It would overturn some of what Obama allies consider his foreign policy achievements
column8: including the Iran deal and his moves toward normal relations with Communist-ruled Cuba. And it criticizes efforts to close the Guantanamo detention center.While not providing figures
column9: it also calls for an end to military rollbacks and demands ""adequate
column10: predictable budgets.""The blueprint includes several departures from foreign policy statements by presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump
column11: whom Ryan has endorsed in the White House race.

column1: It does not demand the erection of a massive wall along the Mexican border
column2: a centerpiece of Trump's campaigning. Ryan calls for border security measures including ""high fencing
column3: aerial surveillance and radar.But it echoes some of Trump's concerns about Muslim immigrants
column4: with calls to tighten refugee screening and discussion of ways not to radicalize youths. Trump sparked outrage by promising to temporarily ban Muslims from the United States.""We must constantly reassess our defenses in order to find and close security gaps so that Islamist militants cannot slip into our country undetected
column5: Ryan's plan said.

column1: The plan is not isolationist. It takes a strong line on battling militants abroad
column2: saying the United States must keep all options on the table and ""eliminate terrorist sanctuaries."" Trump has been critical of some U.S. alliances. Ryan's plan
column3: in contrast
column4: underscores the importance of NATO
column5: calls ties to Israel ""the cornerstone of stability in the Middle East
column6: advocates severe sanctions on Iran and says the United States should stand up to Russian aggression while bolstering Ukraine.

column1: It also calls for more trade agreements and says foreign aid programs should make recipient countries self-sufficient.The plan calls for increased security for diplomats and facilities overseas. In that context
column2: it mentions the 2012 attacks on Benghazi
column3: which many Republicans cite to criticize then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton
column4: Trump's rival in the White House race.Ryan
column5: the country's highest-ranking elected Republican
column6: has described the agenda as a way to offer voters a coherent policy message for 2017. He unveiled an anti-poverty agenda on Monday. Initiatives on regulation
column8: healthcare and tax reform are expected in the coming weeks. (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; Editing by Bernard Orr)"	['Paul'

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-puertorico-debt-congress-idUSKCN0YV04J	Puerto Rico debt bill cleared for Thursday U.S. House vote	"
By Richard Cowan
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Legislation helping Puerto Rico dig out of its $70 billion debt crisis is set for a vote in the U.S. House of Representatives on Thursday after a House panel fended off attempts to open the bill to a series of controversial amendments.By voice vote on Wednesday
column2: the Rules Committee
column3: the gatekeeper for bills moving through the House
column4: sent the Puerto Rico Oversight
column5: Management and Economic Stability Act (PROMESA) to the full House for debate and a likely vote on Thursday.The legislation
column6: the result of months of negotiations between Congress and the Obama administration
column7: would create a federal oversight board to work with investors to determine how much they would recover of the island territory's $70 billion in loans.Republicans have stressed that no taxpayer money would be used to bail out Puerto Rico from a crisis that has left nearly half of the population in poverty amid closings of schools and hospitals and a contracting economy.During a Rules panel debate that stretched into the night
column8: the committee rejected pleas to allow amendments that would have changed the basic structure of the legislation and the operation of the oversight board.If the bill passes the House
column9: action would move to the Senate
column10: where some leading Democrats have said they would seek significant changes.

column1: Earlier on Wednesday
column2: House Natural Resources Committee Chairman Rob Bishop
column3: who ushered the bill through his committee on May 25
column4: told reporters he expected the full House to pass it on Thursday.Bishop
column5: a Utah Republican
column6: said a strong vote for passage in the House would help propel it through the Senate.""The bottom line is the better the vote here (in the House)
column7: the less likely it's going to come back in a significantly altered form"" from the Senate

column1: Supporters hope to get it enacted into law before July 1
column2: when Puerto Rico faces a deadline for making a $1.9 billion debt payment that it might not be able to fulfill.The House Rules Committee voted to allow debate on a limited number of amendments
column3: including one giving priority to protecting federal taxpayer investments in Puerto Rico
column4: such as mass transportation assets.Another amendment expected to be debated would expand a federal program aimed at encouraging economic development in Puerto Rico's ""under-utilized"" business zones.

column1: Representative Raul Grijalva
column2: a senior Democrat who worked on the bill
column3: said Puerto Rico's debt crisis
column4: if unaddressed
column5: could grow into a humanitarian crisis. Stabilization measures contained in the bill
column6: he said
column7: ""would be the first step toward getting the situation under control.""But his fellow Democrat
column10: ""I don't think many of my colleagues in this body appreciate just how deeply offensive the bill before us is regarded in Puerto Rico.""He was particularly concerned with the way control board members would be chosen
column11: with most not having to have any ties to the island.But Gutierrez failed to convince the committee to allow amendments to be offered making changes to the board and its operations. (Reporting by Richard Cowan; Editing by Eric Beech and Andrew Hay; Editing by Michael Perry)"	['Obama']	[]

He pushed the party and challenged them. I thought it made Hillary a better candidate

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-new-york-corruption-mayor-idUSKCN0YV03X	New York mayor strives to stay the course as probe queries persist	"
By Edward Krudy and Gina Cherelus
| NEW YORK

NEW YORK Corruption charges against a union leader and a financier stemming from state and federal investigations that include an examination of New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio's campaign fundraising practices are casting a cloud over his office and could possibly complicate his re-election bid.The arrests on Wednesday of the head of New York City's prison guard union and a hedge fund financier accused of orchestrating a bribery scheme involving union retirement and operating funds were the first to emerge from the probes.Although the charges were not linked to de Blasio
column2: who won a landslide victory in 2013
column3: the case is the first major prosecution to emerge from several overlapping state and federal corruption probes examining de Blasio's fundraising practices
column4: among other avenues of inquiry. David Birdsell
column5: dean of the Baruch College School of Public Affairs
column6: said on Wednesday the investigations were ""keeping him off message
column7: noting that de Blasio was on occasion having to avoid the press because of incessant questions.On Wednesday his office said the investigations were not distracting the mayor.""New Yorkers will vote for the candidate who gets things done for their families and communities
column9: a spokeswoman for de Blasio. ""That person is Mayor de Blasio.""Still
column10: there is evidence that the investigations are affecting the mayor's standing
column11: Birdsell said. If they drag on and raise more questions they will not only be a distraction for the mayor but possibly encourage a challenge from his own party.

column1: Right now people smell some blood in the water
column2: Birdsell said.He said if the mayor becomes directly implicated in the investigations it would turn a contested Democratic primary mayoral race next year into a certainty from a likelihood.On Wednesday at a public appearance
column3: de Blasio reiterated that he was ""absolutely comfortable that we have done things properly."" He has said his administration committed no wrongdoing and is cooperating fully with investigators.In April
column4: de Blasio's office received subpoenas from state and federal prosecutors pursuing coordinated corruption probes that extended from City Hall to the police department.News of the subpoenas came days after a leaked January report from the state Board of Elections accusing the mayor and others of intentionally evading campaign finance contribution limits in 2014.

column1: The mayor's counsel said at the time de Blasio had not been personally served.OFF MESSAGE
column2: RATINGS FALL

column1: The once popular de Blasio
column2: who struck a cord with New Yorkers after 12 years of Michael Bloomberg's mayoralty
column3: has seen his approval rating fall to a new low in May
column4: according to a Quinnipiac University poll.

column1: De Blasio will be up for re-election in 2017.The latest poll
column2: conducted in the first week of June among 600 likely Democratic mayoral primary voters and published on Wednesday
column3: showed 38 percent believed de Blasio deserved reelection while 43 percent said he did not.  The poll was conducted by NYC Deserves Better
column4: a group formed by Bradley Tusk
column5: a businessman and former campaign manager for Michael Bloomberg who wants a new mayor to be elected. The poll found that in a potential match up
column6: de Blasio was neck-and-neck with City Comptroller Scott Stringer.   However
column7: the poll also found that 51 percent had a 'very positive' or 'somewhat positive' opinion of the mayor
column8: and 32 percent had a 'somewhat negative' or 'very negative' opinion.De Blasio brushed off questions about the poll and said he was committed to focusing on the job. ""Polls come and go. They go up. They go down. They don't always reflect what happens in elections
column9: he said. ""I believe fundamentally that the goal is to do the work
column10: do it well (Editing by Bernard Orr)"	[]	[]

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-ohio-marijuana-idUSKCN0YU2U8	Ohio governor signs bill legalizing medical marijuana	"
Republican Ohio Governor John Kasich on Wednesday signed a bill legalizing marijuana use for medical purposes under certain circumstances
column2: his office said.Over the last few years
column3: state legislatures and voters in the United States have been much more receptive to making marijuana legal for medical purposes
column4: and to a lesser extent
column5: recreational use.The Ohio legislature approved the measure in May.Some 24 states and Washington D.C. currently allow some type of medical marijuana use
column6: and just a handful of states allow its recreational use. It remains illegal on the federal level.

column1: Kasich
column2: who earlier this year dropped out of the U.S. presidential race
column3: signed the bill but provided no statement on Wednesday. The Ohio legislation only allows patients with specific medical conditions to use an oil
column4: edible
column5: tincture or vapor form of marijuana prescribed by a physician licensed in the state
column6: starting in 2017.

column1: Medical marijuana users would not be allowed to smoke or grow their own marijuana under the measure
column2: which also would create a commission responsible for regulating and licensing of all operations of the drug.The measure was fast-tracked to head off a possible less-restrictive medical marijuana ballot initiative in November. Ohioans for Medical Marijuana suspended their campaign for the ballot measure late last month
column3: saying that while the lawmakers' bill had its shortcomings
column4: it was ""a moderately good piece of legislation.""

column1: Last November
column2: Ohio voters soundly rejected a measure that would have made it the first U.S. Midwestern state to legalize the recreational use of marijuana. The proposal was criticized for allowing the main backers of the proposal cartel-like powers over the industry in the state for several years. (Reporting by Curtis Skinner in San Francisco and Kim Palmer in Destin
column3: Fla.; Editing by Matthew Lewis)"	['Palmer'
